content: Many jobs will likely be eliminated or significantly re-invented within 24 months due to AI advancements.
The recent advancements in AI, particularly the emergence of 24/7 AI agents, represent the biggest opportunity in human history.
A single developer with a side project recently outcompeted major AI labs, demonstrating that individual innovation can surpass institutional resources.
The 'Jarvis moment' of highly capable AI agents, predicted for 2030, has already arrived.
The next 24 months will bring unprecedented economic transformation, comparable to the Industrial Revolution, driven by AI.
AI models achieving near 100% on benchmarks, while appearing to show diminishing returns, actually represent exponentially increasing capabilities and world-changing potential.
AI models like Gemini 3 Deep Think are achieving gold-level performance in Physics, Math, and Chemistry Olympiads, indicating a 'solution wavefront' propagating from these fields to others.
AI is capable of scientific discovery by solving problems that humans deem too time-consuming or boring, as demonstrated by OpenAI's discovery of new scattering amplitudes in particle physics.
AI's advantages over humans in problem-solving include not needing breaks, not following academic fashion, not skipping boring problems, and being faster, cheaper, and more thorough.
Chemistry, biology, and materials science are next in line to be 'bulk-solved' by AI, following math and physics.
OpenClaw, a 24/7 AI agent framework runnable on a $600 Mac Mini, originated as a side project and was later supported by Sam Altman as an open-source initiative.
AI agents like OpenClaw can perform extensive work autonomously, such as reading documents, organizing files, drafting plans, booking travel, and conducting research, while users are offline.
The global population will use AI to escalate capabilities overnight, not gradually or through traditional GDP percolation.
The country that trains its next generation on AI will win the talent war.
The emergence of AI agents demonstrates a pattern where 'time-rich individuals' can now outproduce 'capital-rich institutions' by leveraging unhobbled existing models.
India possesses the demographics, infrastructure (due to Mukesh Ambani's 5G rollout), and ambition to lead in AI adoption, while China is aging and the US is politically fragmented.
Africa will follow India in skipping the desktop era and going straight to AI-native, similar to how both continents bypassed landlines for mobile technology.
By 2026, the future of technology will be built in cities like Mumbai, Lagos, and Jakarta by young individuals with phones and API keys, not solely in Silicon Valley.
US job growth is experiencing a significant decline, with 181,000 jobs projected for 2025 compared to 1.46 million in 2024, indicating a 'cliff' rather than a slowdown.
Radical and massive job destruction is imminent due to AI, potentially leading to years of devastation unless government intervention occurs.
IBM is tripling entry-level hiring by redesigning roles for junior employees to manage AI agents, and Dropbox CEO Drew Houston notes that younger workers using AI are significantly more productive.
Companies will no longer hire junior talent for on-the-job learning but will instead hire mid-level talent to manage AI agents, effectively removing the bottom rung of the career ladder.
A counterpoint to job destruction is that 80% of AI projects fail due to organizational issues, suggesting AI will augment younger workers first before full automation, providing a transition period.

The solution to AI-driven job market changes is not resistance but preparation, including the implementation of Universal High Income (UHI) to redistribute productivity gains from AI and robotics back to humans.
Technology can achieve the ideals of socialism without the inherent corruption or inefficiency of government.
AI data centers currently consume 7% of US electricity.
OpenAI plans a $100 billion infrastructure investment, and Anthropic has committed to covering 100% of infrastructure upgrade costs for their data centers.
A 'baby's first Dyson swarm' could be built in solar synchronous orbit, appearing as a Saturnian ring from Earth, to solve energy and power demands.
SpaceX aims for 500,000 Starlink V3 satellites, requiring a million Starship launches, which translates to a launch every hour.
The limiting factors for technological advancement are launch rates and chip fabrication, not ambition.
TSMC is investing $165 billion in US fabs, representing 30% of their total output, but these facilities will not be operational for five years.
Whoever solves energy and compute at scale will dominate the next century, with Dyson swarms being a critical infrastructure, not science fiction.
